summary: This document is a detailed log of psychological observations and suicide risk assessments for Jeffrey Epstein during his incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in July and August 2019. It chronicles his mental state, complaints about confinement, interactions with staff and his cellmate, and the mysterious incident on July 23 where a string was found around his neck. The log ends with his death by hanging on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the psychological observation logs. Document details his mental status, complaints about prison conditions, interactions with staff and a cellmate, and the events leading up to his death.

persons.name: I/C
persons.context: An inmate companion who interacted with Epstein in his cell. Epstein discussed topics like prison life, business, investing, and celebrities with this individual.

persons.name: Cellmate
persons.context: An unnamed cellmate who shared a cell with Epstein in the SHU. Epstein accused this person of trying to kill him and called him agitated. The cellmate allegedly called Epstein a pedophile and disposed of a newspaper article about him.

persons.name: Attorney (Palm Beach one)
persons.context: Epstein's attorney from Palm Beach who was present during a conference on July 11, 2019, when Epstein mocked the psychological observer about being placed on suicide watch.

connections.description: Epstein alleged his cellmate tried to kill him by placing a string around his neck. The cellmate was described as agitated, called Epstein a pedophile, and disposed of a newspaper article about him.
Epstein's defense attorney was present during legal visits and conferences, as noted when Epstein made comments about suicide watch in front of him.
Epstein frequently conversed with the inmate companion about business, investing, prison life, and other topics, indicating a social interaction within the prison setting.

events.title: Epstein Arrives in General Population
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrives at the correctional facility and is placed in General Population (GP).

events.title: Initial Intake and Psychological Observation Order
events.description: Epstein undergoes intake screening with no significant mental health history noted. Later, Central Office instructs he be placed on psychological observation as a precaution.

events.title: First Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A 45-minute Suicide Risk Assessment finds no mental health history, substance abuse, suicide history, or current suicidal thoughts. Epstein is future-oriented and wants to speak with his lawyer.

events.title: String Found Around Epstein's Neck
events.description: Epstein is placed on Suicide Watch after a string is found loosely hanging around his neck. He claims not to remember the event, suggesting his cellmate may have been involved.

events.title: Post-Suicide Watch Report
events.description: Epstein states he is fearful of his previous cellmate, who had called him a pedophile. He denies suicidality but reports feeling depressed about his situation.

events.title: Court Inquiry and Incident Report Expunged
events.description: A court sends a form regarding 'suicidal tendencies.' Epstein denies suicidality and mentions his incident report for 'self-mutilation' from July 23 was expunged.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found unresponsive and hanging in the SHU (Special Housing Unit) at 6:30 a.m., ten days after being removed from constant observation.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) - inferred primary location
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein consistently denied being suicidal throughout his incarceration, stating he had 'a wonderful life' and wanted to fight his legal case.
On July 23, 2019, a string was found loosely tied around Epstein's neck. He had no memory of the event and suggested his cellmate might have been responsible.
Epstein expressed fear of his cellmate, who allegedly called him a pedophile and disposed of a newspaper article about him.
Epstein's incident report for 'self-mutilation' related to the July 23 string incident was later expunged, as he mentioned on August 1.
Epstein was found dead by hanging in his SHU cell on August 10, 2019, ten days after being removed from constant psychological observation.
